image.caption: Collection of the U.S. House of Representatives

profileText: A Representative from Texas; born in Pittsburgh, Allegheny County, Pa., August 20, 1935; graduated from Dormont High School, Dormont, Pa., 1953; B.A., Gettysburg College, Gettysburg, Pa., 1957; M.D., Duke University Medical Center, Durham, N.C., 1961; internship and residency training, Henry Ford Hospital, Detroit, Mich., 1961 and 1962; obstetrics and gynecology training, University of Pittsburgh, Pittsburgh, Pa., 1965-1968; medical doctor; United States Air Force, 1963-1965; United States Air National Guard, 1965-1968; delegate, Texas state Republican convention, 1974; unsuccessful candidate for election to the Ninety-fourth Congress in 1974; elected as a Republican to the Ninety-fourth Congress, by special election to fill the vacancy created by the resignation of United States Representative Robert R. Casey (April 3, 1976-January 3, 1977); unsuccessful candidate for reelection to the Ninety-fifth Congress in 1976; elected to the Ninety-sixth and to the two succeeding Congresses (January 3, 1979-January 3, 1985); was not a candidate for reelection to the House of Representatives in 1984, but was an unsuccessful candidate for nomination to the United States Senate; author; unsuccessful Libertarian Party candidate for election for President of the United States in 1988; elected as a Republican to the One Hundred Fifth and to the seven succeeding Congresses (January 3, 1997-January 3, 2013); unsuccessful candidate for the Republican nomination for President of the United States in 2008 and in 2012; was not a candidate for reelection to the One Hundred Thirteenth Congress in 2012.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: Doherty, Brian. Ron Paul's Revolution: The Man and the Movement He Inspired. New York: Broadside Books, 2012.
Haddad, Philip and Roger Marsh, eds. Ron Paul Speaks. With an Introduction by Ron Paul. Guilford, CT: The Lyons Press, 2008.
Paul, Ron. Gold, Peace, and Prosperity: The Birth of a New Currency. 1981. Reprint Edition, Auburn, AL: The Ludwig Von Mises Institute of Auburn University, 2007.
___. The Case for Gold: A Minority Report of the U. S. Gold Commission. Washington, D. C.: Cato Institute, 1982.
___. Abortion and Liberty. Lake Jackson, TX: Foundation for Rational Economics and Education, 1983.
___. Freedom Under Siege: The U. S. Constitution After 200-Plus Years. 1987. Reprint Edition, Auburn, AL: The Ludwig von Mises Institute of Auburn University, 2007.
___. Mises and Austrian Economics: A Personal View. Auburn, AL: The Ludwig von Mises Institute of Auburn University, 2004.
___. A Foreign Policy of Freedom: Peace, Commerce, and Honest Friendship. Lake Jackson, TX: Foundation for Rational Economics and Education, 2007.
___. The Revolution: A Manifesto. New York: Grand Central Publishing, 2008.
___. Pillars of Prosperity: Free Markets, Honest Money, Private Property. Auburn AL: The Ludwig von Mises Institute of Auburn University, 2008.
___. End the Fed. New York: Grand Central Publishing, 2009.
___. Liberty Defined: 50 Essential Issues That Affect Our Freedom. New York: Grand Central Publishing, 2011.

researchRecord.name: 1978-1988, 5 commercials on 1 film reel, 1 videoreel, and 2 videocassettes.
researchRecord.description: The commercials were used during Ron Paul's campaigns for the 1978 U.S. congressional election in District 22 of Texas and the 1988 presidential election, Republican and Libertarian parties respectively.

recordLocation.name: The Julian P. Kanter Political Commercial Archive, Department of Communication

researchRecord.name: In the Congressional Election, 1976 collection, 0.5 linear foot.
researchRecord.description: This collection consists of campaign material from Houstonâ€™s 1976 Congressional election. The two races were between Bob Gammage and Ron Paul and between Nick Gearhart and Bob Eckhardt.
